Message.Title: Muni defaults still rare, but alarming trend developing, Moody’s says
Message.Msg: Muni defaults still rare, but alarming trend developing, Moody’s says May 7, 2013, 4:42 PM It was less than three years ago that Meredith Whitney, famed banking bear, was making her next call that 50 to 100 sizable municipalities would default on their bonds in the near future. That hasn’t come to pass, and Moody’s’ latest assessment of municipal bond defaults in 2012 surprised few people Tuesday when it tallied a total of five defaults that it rated. That’s not to say the number of defaults isn’t climbing: the tally of five in 2012 compares to an annual average of 1.3 between 1970 and 2007. Between 2008 and 2012, defaults averaged 4.6 per year. And the majority of defaulters are not rated by Moody’s, nor any other agency. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York puts its total between 1970 and 2011 at 2,521. Moody’s, however, picks up on a more alarming trend. While in the past defaults were usually confined to specific projects like healthcare facilities and housing infrastructure, the most recent year saw general governments take three of the five spots. Rating analysts, led by Merxe Tudela, write: “As 2012 progressed, the stress felt by general governments not only continued, but produced a number of defaults and bankruptcies among towns and cities. Three of the five Moody’s-rated defaults were municipal governments rather than healthcare or housing projects. Historically these are quite rare; there have been ten general government defaults of various security types between 1970 and 2012 (i.e., GO, limited tax, and lease obligations), for a rate of one general government default every 4.3 years. Since the onset of the financial crisis, the pace has accelerated to one general government default per year.” The three cities: Wanatchee WA, Stockton, CA, and Oakdale, CA. San Bernardino, CA, not rated by Moody’s but currently sitting in bankruptcy court, is another notable 2012 defaulter. In the last 100 years, the only time default rates have climbed to a substan

Message.Title: Kansas governor, Attorney General Holder spar over new state gun-rights law
Message.Msg: TOPEKA, Kan. – U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has told Kansas Gov. Sam Brownback that a new state law attempting to block federal regulation of some guns is unconstitutional and that the federal government is willing to go to court over the issue. Kansas' law declares that the federal government has no authority to regulate guns, ammunition and accessories manufactured, sold and kept only in Kansas. The law also makes it a felony for a federal agent to enforce any law, regulation, order or treaty covering those items.

Message.Title: Putin blames struggling global economy for Russia's economic problems
Message.Msg: (Reuters) - Facing protests, and with his popularity recently at a 12-year low, Putin has been trying to deflect the blame for a stagnating economy, which threatens to arrest the rise in living standards that has underpinned his support. He says a struggling global economy, particularly the euro zone, is to blame for growth falling to just 1.1 percent year-on-year in the first quarter, down from almost 5 percent a year earlier.

Message.Title: Snarky buzzwords in article headlines that make me want to puke everytime I see them.
Message.Msg: "Fresh" - connotation is that once a problem or issue has been dealt with to its conclusion, there is always something new and unexpected AND NEGATIVE around the corner. There is always some "fresh" lawsuit, putback claim, etc. No weighting scale is ever applied by the author to the facts underlying the claim or the liklihood of success of such claims. It's all new and "fresh" and therefore must be relevant and consequential. "Mull" - when some third-party may or may not make a decision or take some action which will be pivotol (according to an author) to the sucess or utter collapse of a company. The decision maker who is "mulling" something is usualy bestowed immense decision powers over the company involved by the author of the article. Generally the investors of the company should be aware they are in the cross-hairs of this would be decision maker who also has the attention of plaintiffs, regulators, and government officials. Although the "mull-er" has these immense god-like powers, they may choose to either be benevolent and do nothing or strike like Zeus from Mt. Olympus. Either way, they are indifferent - but the article writter wants you to know they are there and ready to pounce at a moments notice. So beware. "Plunge" - earnings may be off a few cents or the pps may have dropped a percent or a few pennies but this buzzword makes you think your investment is headed to pink-sheet territory.

Message.Title: Two Recent Biggest Positions in Irving Kahn's Portfolio.
Message.Msg: The oldest living investment professional, Irving Kahn, 107 years old, has managed to increase the market value of his long holdings by more than 17.8% in the past three months, from $576 million in the last quarter 2012 to more than $678.7 million in the first quarter 2013. According to his 13F filing, his top two positions are Pfizer (NYSE: PFE) and Citigroup (NYSE: C). Those two positions combined accounted for 28.1% of his total portfolio. Moreover, he has kept adding more shares into those two companies in the first quarter 2013.
